[[Jim Molan]] |identification_symbol=[[File:1st Brigade (Australia) Unit Colour patch.png|75px]] |identification_symbol_label=Brigade Colour Patch |specialization= |current_commander=Brigadier Ben James, [[Member of the Order of Australia|AM]], [[Distinguished Service Medal (Australia)|DSM]] |ceremonial_chief= |ceremonial_chief_label= }} '''1st Brigade''' is a combined arms formation of the [[Australian Army]]. Raised for service initially in 1914 for service during World War I, the brigade fought at [[Gallipoli campaign|Gallipoli]] and on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] before being disbanded in mid-1919. In 1921, the 1st Brigade was re-raised as a unit of Australia's part-time military forces, based in [[New South Wales]]. During World War II the brigade undertook defensive duties before being disbanded. In 1948, it was re-raised as an integral part of the Australian Regular Army. Currently the brigade is based at [[Robertson Barracks]] in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] and at [[RAAF Base Edinburgh]] near [[Adelaide, South Australia]]. It is the first of the Australian Army brigades to be re-organised as a combat brigade under [[Plan Beersheba]]. ==History== ===World War I=== The 1st Brigade was raised in [[Sydney, New South Wales]], shortly after the start of World War I in August 1914 for service overseas as part of the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] (AIF). Upon formation it consisted of four infantry [[battalion]]s—the [[1st Battalion (Australia)|1st]], [[2nd Battalion (Australia)|2nd]], [[3rd Battalion (Australia)|3rd]] and [[4th Battalion (Australia)|4th]]{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11189.asp |title=2nd Battalion |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=26 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110607032045/http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11189.asp| archivedate= 7 June 2011 | deadurl= no}}—however, later it received organic fire support when the 1st Australian Machine Gun Company (February 1916 to February 1918) and 1st Australian Trench Mortar Battery (from April 1916) were added to its order of battle.{{cite web|title=1st Australian Division 1914–1918|accessdate=2 November 2009|publisher=The Long Long Trail|url=http://www.1914-1918.net/1ausdiv.htm}} Assigned to the [[1st Division (Australia)|1st Division]], the brigade's first commanding officer was Colonel [[Henry Normand MacLaurin|Henry MacLaurin]].Grey 2008, p. 88. During the war, the 1st Brigade took part in the fighting at [[Gallipoli campaign|Gallipoli]] and on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in France and Belgium, before being disbanded in April 1919.{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM4/23/AWM4-23-1-46.pdf |title=AWM 4/23/1/46 Australian Imperial Force unit war diaries: 1st Infantry Brigade (March – April 1919) |publisher=Australian War Memorial |format=PDF |accessdate=26 April 2011}} Notable battles in which the brigade fought include: [[Battle of Lone Pine|Lone Pine]], [[Battle of Pozières|Pozières]], [[Second Battle of Bullecourt|Bullecourt]], [[Battle of Passchendaele|Passchendaele]], [[Battle of Hazebrouck|Hazebrouck]], [[Battle of Amiens (1918)|Amiens]] and the [[Hindenburg Line]].{{cite web |archiveurl=http://classic-web.archive.org/web/20070617134323/www.diggerhistory.info/pages-army-today/brigades/01bde.htm |url=http://www.diggerhistory.info/pages-army-today/brigades/01bde.htm |title=1 Brigade |publisher=Digger History.info |archivedate=2 July 2011 |accessdate=2 July 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11188.asp |title=1st Battalion |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=3 May 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110514115728/http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11188.asp| archivedate= 14 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} Five soldiers from 1st Brigade units received the [[Victoria Cross]], Australia's highest military decoration, for their actions during the war. These were: [[John Patrick Hamilton|John Hamilton]], [[George Howell (VC)|George Howell]], [[Bede Kenny|Thomas Kenny]], [[Leonard Keysor]] and [[Alfred Shout]].{{cite web|url=http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/History.asp |title=History – HQ 1st Brigade – Forces Command |publisher= Australian Army |accessdate=26 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110609040558/http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/History.asp| archivedate= 9 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} ===Inter war years and World War II=== In 1921, the Australian military was re-organised as the units of the part-time forces were re-organised to perpetuate the numerical designations and structures of the AIF.Grey 2008, p. 125. As a result, the 1st Brigade was re-raised as a part-time formation of the [[Australian Army Reserve|Citizens Forces]] based in [[Newcastle, New South Wales]], and consisting of four infantry battalions: the [[13th Battalion (Australia)|13th]], [[33rd Battalion (Australia)|33rd]], [[35th Battalion (Australia)|35th]] and [[41st Battalion (Australia)|41st Battalions]].{{cite web|url=http://www.diggerhistory.info/pages-badges/patches/infantry.htm |title=Australian Infantry Unit Colour Patches 1921–49 |publisher=Digger History |accessdate=26 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712164357/http://www.diggerhistory.info/pages-badges/patches/infantry.htm |archivedate=12 July 2007}} Initially the brigade was staffed through the [[Conscription in Australia|compulsory training scheme]], which meant that the brigade was able to maintain its numbers, however, in 1922, following the signing of the [[Washington Naval Treaty]], Australia's security concerns were reduced. As a result, the Army's budget was halved and the scope of the compulsory training scheme was scaled back; with this the authorised strength of each infantry battalion was reduced to just 409 men of all ranks.Palazzo 2002, pp. 65–67. In 1929, the compulsory training scheme was suspended by the newly elected [[James Scullin|Scullin]] Labor government and was replaced by a voluntary system,Grey 2008, p. 138. under the new name of the "Militia".Palazzo 2001, p. 110. This, coupled with the financial hardships of the [[Great Depression]], meant that there were few volunteers available for service and many units had to be amalgamated or disbanded.Keogh 1965, p. 44. As a result, the 1st Brigade was reduced to just three infantry battalions. Upon the outbreak of World War II in September 1939, the 1st Brigade consisted of the 13th, 33rd and 41st Battalions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ordersofbattle.com/UnitData.aspx?UniX=6223&Tab=Sub&Titl=1%20Australian%20Infantry%20Brigade |title=1 Australian Infantry Brigade: Subordinates |publisher=Orders of Battle.com |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{dead link|date=May 2015}} Initially, upon the commencement of hostilities it was decided to call up the Militia to undertake periods of continuous training in order to boost the nation's readiness for war, however, following Japan's entry into the war in December 1941, they were mobilised for defensive duties. Although some Militia units were committed to combat operations in [[New Guinea]] from 1942 onwards, the 1st Brigade remained in Australia for the duration of the war, headquartered around [[Parramatta, New South Wales]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ozatwar.com/ausarmy/ausarmyapr1943.htm |title=Composition of the Australian Army in April 1943 |publisher=Australia @ War |author=Dunn, Peter |accessdate=26 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110602205015/http://ozatwar.com/ausarmy/ausarmyapr1943.htm| archivedate= 2 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} where it formed part of the 1st Division.{{cite web |url=http://www.ordersofbattle.com/UnitData.aspx?UniX=6223&Tab=Sup&Titl=1%20Australian%20Infantry%20Brigade |title=1 Australian Infantry Brigade: Superiors |publisher=Orders of Battle.com |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{dead link|date=May 2015}} By the end of hostilities, it consisted of only one battalion—the 41st/2nd Battalion—as other units had been transferred, amalgamated or disbanded. Between May 1942 and August 1945 it was commanded by Brigadier Frederick Burrows.{{cite web |url=http://www.ordersofbattle.com/UnitData.aspx?UniX=6223&Tab=App&Titl=1%20Australian%20Infantry%20Brigade |title=1 Australian Infantry Brigade: Appointments |publisher=Orders of Battle.com |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{dead link|date=May 2015}} ===Post World War II=== Following the end of hostilities in August 1945, the existing structures were disbanded throughout 1945 and into 1946 and the Interim Army was raised.Horner and Bou 2008, pp. 41–42. As a part of this, the [[34th Brigade (Australia)|34th Brigade]] was raised for occupation duties in Japan.Grey 2008, p. 203. In 1948, with the establishment of the reformation of the Regular Army and the raising of the Australian Regiment (later known as the [[Royal Australian Regiment]]), the 34th Brigade was renamed the 1st Brigade following its return to Australia.Kuring 2004, p. 219. During the [[Korean War]], individual elements of the brigade were detached for combat in Korea, although they were subsequently placed under the command of other formations. In 1960, the Australian Army adopted the [[Pentropic organisation|Pentropic divisional establishment]].Grey 2008, p. 227. This saw the adoption of the five battalion division and resulted in the disbandment of the old three battalion brigade formations.Kuring 2004, p. 262. As a result, the 1st Brigade, including its headquarters, was disbanded.Blaxland 1989, p. 64. In late 1964, however, the decision was made to end the experiment with the Pentropic establishment,McNeill 1993, p. 22. partly because of the difficulties it created with allied interoperability.Grey 2008, p. 228. Early the following year the brigade formations were re-established, although they were designated "task forces" instead of brigades.McCarthy 2003, p. 131.Blaxland 1989, p. 108. In mid-1965 1 RAR, was sent to Vietnam as part of Australia's commitment to the [[Vietnam War|ongoing conflict]] in that country. In early 1966, the decision to increase the Australian Army's presence in Vietnam from one infantry battalion to two was announced. In order to command this force, it was decided to form an Australian task force. Shortly after this, the 1st Task Force, consisting of the [[5th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] (5 RAR), undertook a readiness exercise around Gospers in New South Wales.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 152. Once this exercise was successfully completed, the 1st Task Force's headquarters was used to raise the [[1st Australian Task Force]] and was dispatched to Vietnam, where it would remain until the end of the Australian involvement. In 1972, the task force returned to Australia and had units located at [[Holsworthy Barracks|Holsworthy]] in New South Wales, [[Woodside Barracks|Woodside]] in South Australia and at [[Puckapunyal]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. In 1982, the "brigade" designations were readopted.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 268. Brigadier John Sheldrick was in command of the brigade at the time and early the year the [[1st Armoured Regiment (Australia)|1st Armoured Regiment]] was placed under the 1st Brigade's command as part of the Army's mechanisation trials. The new role of the 1st Brigade as a mechanised force was confirmed in 1983 and following this the capability was developed. This saw the [[5th/7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] (5/7 RAR), re-equipped with [[armoured personnel carrier]]s, which they began to receive in July 1983.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 270. During the 1980s, one of the brigade's other infantry battalions, the [[3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], began developing the Australian Army's parachute capability, and by late 1983 it had become a specialised parachute infantry battalion.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 274. They were later transferred to the [[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Brigade]].Horner and Bou 2008, p. 291. ===Recent years=== [[File:Tandem thurst 01.jpg|thumb|A soldier of the 5/7th Battalion, The Royal Australian Regiment, conducts fire and movement during training here.]] In 1992, the brigade began the process of moving to Darwin as part of a force structure review focused upon relocating defence assets in the north. By 2000, the brigade had completed its move and was headquartered in Robertson Barracks in Darwin. Before the move was complete, the brigade was warned out to support the 3rd Brigade's deployment to [[INTERFET|East Timor]] and in October 1999, 5/7 RAR began deploying.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 312. They returned to Australia in April 2000.Horner and Bou 2008, p. 314. As part of the Hardened and Networked Army initiative 5/7 RAR was de-linked in 2006 to form two mechanised battalions. 5 RAR remained in Darwin, while the 7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (7 RAR), along elements of the 1st Combat Service Support Battalion was moved to Adelaide, where they are now based at [[RAAF Base Edinburgh]].{{cite web|url=http://www.army.gov.au/1BDE_ADEL/ |title=Home – 1st Brigade (Adelaide) Relocation – Forces Command |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=26 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402081329/http://www.army.gov.au/1BDE_ADEL/ |archivedate=2 April 2011 }} Although the brigade is split, the [[Adelaide-Darwin Railway|Adelaide–Darwin Railway]] can be used to transport heavy vehicles and equipment north. In its current configuration, the brigade is currently capable of operating three [[battlegroup (army)|battlegroups]], one formed around 1st Armoured Regiment as an armour-heavy formation and the other two around 5 RAR and 7 RAR operating as mechanised infantry formations.{{cite web|url=http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/ |title=Home – HQ 1st Brigade – Forces Command |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=26 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608115748/http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/ |archivedate=8 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} In the past decade units of the brigade have undertaken deployments to East Timor, [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]]. ===Planned restructure=== In late 2011, the Australian government announced that under a restructuring program known as [[Plan Beersheba]], the 1st, 3rd and 7th Brigades would be reformed as combined arms Combat Brigades.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-12-12/defence-announces-major-army-restructure/3726630|title=Defence announces major Army restructure|publisher=ABC Online|date=12 December 2011| accessdate= 12 December 2011 }} Each will have a similar structure and capabilities, consisting of: a Brigade Headquarters, an Armoured Cavalry Regiment, two Standard Infantry Battalions, an Artillery Regiment, a Combat Engineer Regiment, a Combat Service Support Battalion and a Combat Signals Regiment.{{cite web|url=http://www.army.gov.au/Our-future/Projects/Plan-BEERSHEBA/Multi-role-Combat-Brigades|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408081650/http://army.gov.au/Our-future/Projects/Plan-BEERSHEBA/Multi-role-Combat-Brigades|archivedate=8 April 2014|title=Multi-role Combat Brigades|publisher=Australian Army|accessdate=1 May 2014|deadurl=no}} Under the new plan, the 2nd Cavalry Regiment was transferred to the 3rd Brigade in October–November 2014, transitioning to the ACR structure.{{cite web |url=http://www.oyetimes.com/news/australia/74714-2nd-cavalry-regiment-arrives-in-townsville |title=2nd Cavalry Regiment Arrives in Townsville |work=Oye! Times |date=29 November 2014 |accessdate=1 December 2014}} ==Present formation== As at 2011 the 1st Brigade was made up of the following units:{{cite web|url=http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/1st_Brigade_Units.asp |title=1st Brigade Units – HQ 1st Brigade – Forces Command |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=26 April 2011|archivedate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110602115629/http://www.army.gov.au/hq1bde/1st_Brigade_Units.asp }} *Headquarters 1st Brigade; *[[1st Armoured Regiment (Australia)|1st Armoured Regiment]] (Armoured Cavalry Regiment); *[[5th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]]; *[[7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]]; *[[8th/12th Regiment, Royal Australian Artillery]]; *[[1st Combat Engineer Regiment (Australia)|1st Combat Engineer Regiment]] ([[Combat Engineers]]); *1st Combat Signal Regiment; *1st Combat Service Support Battalion. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Blaxland|first=J.C.|title=Organising an Army: The Australian Experience, 1957–1965|url=http://ips.cap.anu.edu.au/publications/organising-army-australian-experience-1957-1965|year=1989|publisher=Strategic and Defence Studies Centre, the Research School of Pacific Studies, the Australian National University|location=Canberra|isbn=0-7315-0530-1}} *{{cite book|last=Grey |first=Jeffrey |authorlink=Jeffrey Grey |title=A Military History of Australia |edition=3rd |publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Melbourne, Victoria|year=2008|series= |url= |isbn=978-0-521-69791-0}} *{{cite book|last=Horner|first=David|author2=Bou, Jean|title=Duty First. A History of the Royal Australian Regiment|year=2008|edition=2nd|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=Sydney, New South Wales|isbn=978-1-74175-374-5}} *{{cite book|last=Keogh|first=Eustace|title=South West Pacific 1941–45|year=1965|publisher=Grayflower Publications|location=Melbourne, Victoria|isbn=|oclc=7185705}} *{{cite book|last=Kuring |first=Ian |authorlink= |year=2004 |title=Redcoats to Cams: A History of Australian Infantry 1788–2001 |publisher=Australian Military Historical Publications |location=Loftus, New South Wales |isbn=1-876439-99-8}} *{{cite book|last=McCarthy|first=Dayton|title=The Once and Future Army: A History of the Citizen Military Forces, 1947–74|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=South Melbourne|isbn=0-19-551569-2}} *{{cite book|last=McNeill |first=Ian |author2= |title=To Long Tan: The Australian Army and the Vietnam War 1950–1966|series=The Official History of Australia's Involvement in Southeast Asian Conflicts 1948–1975 |publisher=Allen and Unwin |location=St Leonards, New South Wales |year=1993 |edition= |isbn=1-86373-282-9}} *{{cite book|last=Palazzo|first=Albert|author2= |title=The Australian Army: A History of its Organisation 1901–2001|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Melbourne, Victoria |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-19-551506-0}} *{{cite book| last = Palazzo| first = Albert| authorlink = | year = 2002| title = Defenders of Australia: The 3rd Australian Division 1916–1991| publisher = Australian Military Historical Publications| location = Loftus, New South Wales| isbn = 1-876439-03-3}} {{Refend}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} [[Category:Brigades of Australia|1]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1916]] [[Category:1916 establishments in Australia]]
